post.author: Renholder
post.body:
I might be the outcast here. Well maybe not.

My top bands are currently ,

Tool - ( last album was lateralus [2001] , Quite frankly .a modern masterpiece , those who haven't heard tool or disliked their previous efforts should check this album out... outstanding stuff)

Incubus- (yeah people say they've gone mellow. I dont believe that crap. They manage to sound original all the time )

Muse- (i've only recently started getting into this British band... Good stuff
A Perfect Circle - ( New album coming out on the 16th..mark your calender.... Thirteenth step...I saw their concert a couple of weeks ago... amazing band.)

That's about it all I'm listening to at this moment...

post.author: jizaboz
post.body:
Quote:
Oh, and Linkin Park, but they're not really metal in my opinion.[/QUOTE]


... yeah more like EMO heh-heh

ha "Suffocation". Band with 2 black dudes in it... saw them on cable metal music station. Yet ANOTHER metal band with a singer who sounds exactly like cookie monster from Sesame Street heh-heh.

post.author: Dinky
post.body:
jizaboz wrote:
Quote:
Oh, and Linkin Park, but they're not really metal in my opinion.[/QUOTE]


... yeah more like EMO heh-heh

ha "Suffocation". Band with 2 black dudes in it... saw them on cable metal music station. Yet ANOTHER metal band with a singer who sounds exactly like cookie monster from Sesame Street heh-heh.


Linkin Park is sort of like Emo and Boy Bands mixed together (their singing creates the boy-band sound to me). But the guy who makes the actual instrumental part of the music is a genius. Most of the Linkin Park music sounds AMAZING to me until the guys start singing.

Then again it's like that for me and a lot of music. I never listen to lyrics, I just jam to the instruments. So if the singer is over-the-top, then I probably won't like the band unfortunately. Err maybe I shouldn't say over-the-top, maybe I should say that they created their music with trying to center the attention around the singer instead of the actual sound.

I prefer to listen to instrumentals sometimes. Like, here's a REALLY good Joe Satriani song, it's called Searching...

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l_Mq2X2RvBo

post.author: Dinky
post.body:
jizaboz wrote:
Quote:
Oh, and Linkin Park, but they're not really metal in my opinion.[/QUOTE]


... yeah more like EMO heh-heh

ha "Suffocation". Band with 2 black dudes in it... saw them on cable metal music station. Yet ANOTHER metal band with a singer who sounds exactly like cookie monster from Sesame Street heh-heh.


Linkin Park is sort of like Emo and Boy Bands mixed together (their singing creates the boy-band sound to me). But the guy who makes the actual instrumental part of the music is a genius. Most of the Linkin Park music sounds AMAZING to me until the guys start singing.

Then again it's like that for me and a lot of music. I never listen to lyrics, I just jam to the instruments. So if the singer is over-the-top, then I probably won't like the band unfortunately. Err maybe I shouldn't say over-the-top, maybe I should say that they created their music with trying to center the attention around the singer instead of the actual sound.

I prefer to listen to instrumentals sometimes. Like, here's a REALLY good Joe Satriani song, it's called Searching...

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l_Mq2X2RvBo

post.author: Sparky
post.body:
I've been avoiding this thread, but it's got me tied to the chair and is threatening to do horrible things to me unless I hit "reply".
Currently acquainting myself with:
Melt-Banana
Deerhoof

Established favorites:
David Bowie*
Michael Jackson (Bad and Thriller)
Philip Glass (I refuse to link to his site because he's a pretentious creep and has a huge photo of himself pontificating on the splash screen)
NIN (pre-Fragile)
Rammstein (English translations of lyrics here: http://herzeleid.com/en/lyrics)
Cibo Matto
Pixies (Surfer Rosa and Doolittle particularly)
A Clockwork Orange soundtrack
Simon and Garfunkel
And... crap, how could I forget Madonna?

*
For those interested in learning about David Bowie, here are my takes on a few of his albums:
"Let's Dance" is concise, ridiculously over the top, and very '80's. Highly recommended.
"Scary Monsters" is very strange, but very consistent, and I hated it at first. Now it's one of my favorite albums. "Ashes to Ashes" is awesome. The vocal work is obscenely weird. It's very fun to sing along with.
"Earthling" is "Outside" is very hard to like, but after you listen to it 23,000 times you might like it. Well, that's what happened to me, anyway.
"The Rise and Fall of Ziggy Stardust and the Spiders From Mars" is probably his best known album.
"Diamond Dogs" is a set of songs inspired by George Orwell's book "1984".
It's a lot more fun if you enjoyed the book.
"Hunky Dory" is incredibly consistent, but might scare some people off. It's very lyrical, and has lots of piano in it. Don't say I didn't warn you.

post.author: Burrito
post.body:
If you want to know more about Wendy Carlos, the composer of the Clockwork Orange soundtrack and quite an interesting person:

http://www.wendycarlos.com

Very interesting site, i spend hours reading there. She also pretty much pioneered electronic music...but you knew this, right?

post.author: MBolus
post.body:
Burrito wrote:
If you want to know more about Wendy Carlos, the composer of the Clockwork Orange soundtrack and quite an interesting person: http://www.wendycarlos.com
Very interesting site, i spend hours reading there. She also pretty much pioneered electronic music...but you knew this, right?

I enjoy a lot of Carlos' music.

They seem not to have mellowed too much over the years, and in fact seem to have gone on to force a bit of history to be rewritten and redefined in some ways. This is incidentally one of those musicians who has a lot of references still quoted one way on Google, but clicking on the links lead to completely redone sentences with different meanings. Of course, creative artists are often different anyway. I know a lot about one of Carlos' pet peeves from scientific and philosophical viewpoints, including the spectrum or continuum of identity. In other words, where does gray become close enough to black or white to be classified as such. In their mind, they already had one identity when they achieved early success, but had to undergo much more concrete changes to have others sort of accept that identity.

A Clockwork Orange was excellent, and was one of those films in which the soundtrack played a strong role. Carlos and Moog (RIP last month) had quite a synergistic relationship.

post.author: jizaboz
post.body:
Quote:
She also pretty much pioneered electronic music

What about Ron Grainer? The inventor of the theme from Dr. Who? I think this Wendy chick Remixed it though.

post.author: Burrito
post.body:
jizaboz wrote:
Quote:
She also pretty much pioneered electronic music

What about Ron Grainer? The inventor of the theme from Dr. Who? I think this Wendy chick Remixed it though.

Ron Grainer was "just" the composer of the score. They were realised by Delia Derbyshire at the BBC Radiophonic Workshop. Since this was around 1963 and Wendy Carlos' first album appeared 1968, Delia Derbyshire can also be counted in as a pioneer of electronic music i'd say.

post.author: David_Mac
post.body:
Ron Grainer actually wrote the bass line for the doctor who theme, and little else. Wendy experimented heavily with chopping and rearranging high-density audio tape (thats' how she got those groovy fade effects), and wrote many interesting papers suggesting that emotive musics follow a predictable mathematical sequence... dang I'm going to go and check that link- is probably all there.

Favorite bands atm? Gun Club, Grey Daturas, Jesus n Mary Chain & The Cramps. hubba hubba.

post.body:
I haven't actually read any of the previous posts since this is such a large thread, but here are some bands that I do like.

Type O Negative is still my favorite

Venom

Dimmu Borgir

Creed

Ozzy Osbourne's Blizzard of Ozz and Black Sabbath

Nine Inch Nails

I like Marilyn Manson, not because of the lyrics but the sound of the music... in my opinion he just seems more like shock factor for the next generation of goths

Fear Factory

Soundgarden

Puddle of Mudd

some Smile Empty Soul

Manmade God

I have soundtracks for Gladiator, Braveheart and The Crow

the Quake soundtrack which is by far the best game music in my opinion

I have some Led Zeppelin

I used to listen to Insane Clown Posse and Twiztid but got tired of what they were singing about (it was mostly about the sound anyway)

Then there's miscellaneous music, ranging from rock and metal to black metal and death metal, whatever the hell the difference is anyway.

Basically, I like music that sounds good, regardless of it being mainstream or underground. None of the above is underground, but I mention such because of the internet radio station hosted by vampirefreaks.com. I haven't really heard many of the bands played on there before. I like that station because it's a good source of random black and death metal as well as the occasional sound not mentioned in my post.

For me, music is not so much about the lyrics but rather the melody and where that sound takes my imagination and mood. I do care about lyrics, mostly from Type O Negative, Venom, Nine Inch Nails Creed and whatever else I may not have listed, but they are not the immediate deciding factor for how good a song is.

edit: I also like Nirvana and Alice In Chains as well. Some older stuff like Nazareth is good. My tastes are not confined to a definitive period of time or style of music, except rap and country.

post.author: Bauul
post.body:
seighten wrote:
Then there's miscellaneous music, ranging from rock and metal to black metal and death metal, whatever the hell the difference is anyway.


going from everyone's understanding of Classic Rock (Think Led Zep, Deep Purple, the Stones etc.), Heavy (or classic) Metal is rock with all traces of the blues removed, think Sabbath, Judas Priest or Maiden.

Taking heavy metal as the blue print for all the other kinds of metal, if you take out the "epicness" of the music, make it heavier, faster and the vocals more deep and growly, you have Thrash metal, e.g. Metallica, Anthrax, Slayer or Megadeth.

Increase the speed of Thrash even more, make it even more heavy and take all hint of melody out of the vocals, reducing them completely to growls and grunts, you have Death metal, e.g. Deicide and Cannibal Corpse. Taken to it's extreme conclusion (as fast, as heavy and as violent as you can get whilst still being music) you get Grindcore, e.g. early Napalm Death.

Again take Thrash, but this time combine it with Hip-Hop and R 'n' B, and you have Nu-Metal (Linkin Cock etc.)

Again with thrash, combine it with Hardcore Punk and you have Metalcore, the current popular style, think Dillinger Escape Plan or Killswitch Engage.

Going back to Heavy Metal, make the songs faster, more gothic sounding and more grand in their conception, and instead of singing the words shriek or screech them, you have Black Metal (Cradle of Filth are the mainstream example, think Mayhem for a more pure example).

Once again take Heavy Metal, but 'glam it up', make the vocals more sleazy and make the songs more simple and cheesy than they are, and you have Hollywood Glam Metal (.e.g Motely Crue, Kiss). Take this to it's extreme conclusion (ultra fast, ultra cheesy and more spandex and flowery shirts than your eyes can take) and you have Power Metal (e.g. Gamma Ray).

That's basically it, most bands will fall into one or a combination of these catgories. The easiest method of telling genres apart is the vocals, followed by the speed, heaviness and general sound of the music underneath.

so, it would look like this:

Code:
Vocals:
Sounds like a Woman ------------------------------------ Sounds like an Ogre
Power, Heavy, Glam, Thrash, Nu / Metalcore (varies), Black, Death, Grindcore


Roughly anyway. Ish.

Hope that helps!

post.author: Dinky
post.body:
jizaboz wrote:
Quote:
Oh, and Linkin Park, but they're not really metal in my opinion.[/QUOTE]


... yeah more like EMO heh-heh

ha "Suffocation". Band with 2 black dudes in it... saw them on cable metal music station. Yet ANOTHER metal band with a singer who sounds exactly like cookie monster from Sesame Street heh-heh.


Linkin Park is sort of like Emo and Boy Bands mixed together (their singing creates the boy-band sound to me). But the guy who makes the actual instrumental part of the music is a genius. Most of the Linkin Park music sounds AMAZING to me until the guys start singing.

Then again it's like that for me and a lot of music. I never listen to lyrics, I just jam to the instruments. So if the singer is over-the-top, then I probably won't like the band unfortunately. Err maybe I shouldn't say over-the-top, maybe I should say that they created their music with trying to center the attention around the singer instead of the actual sound.

I prefer to listen to instrumentals sometimes. Like, here's a REALLY good Joe Satriani song, it's called Searching...

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l_Mq2X2RvBo

post.author: Starbuck
post.body:
Soundgarden
My favourite band of all time, although I don't listen to them much anymore, I know the songs so well there isn't much point it seems. Glad to see some people mentioning them in their list (Hi Static, by the way). My favourite album of theirs is Superunknown just like everybody else :/ but Down on the Upside comes close. Incredible music if you're a grungehead or metalhead, and just as essential listening if you're not, like me. Songs I love the most:

The Day I Tried to Live

Bleed Together
The last song they recorded, I believe

Blow Up the Outside World

Pretty noose
It got me into them in the first place

Blackhole Sun
Unoriginal choice, but it has to be on the list

Like Suicide

Beyond the Wheel
Extra singing credit... "mother, who's your man!!"

Big Dumb Sex
To prove they could do catchy pop-rock songs if they wanted

And many many more.



The Pixies
You must have heard these guys. If you haven't, you've probably heard music geeks/musicians going on about them. Very difficult to describe their stuff. It's weird, yes. They sound like a surf band sometimes, they sound spanish sometimes. It's difficult to get across how different they sound to anything before them and how much they influenced bands that came after them. Kurt Cobain once said that Nirvana was his attempt to rip-off the Pixies, and if you listen to the song Gouge Away, you'll hear what he meant. Although this view isn't widely shared, my favourite album is Bossanova... but if you want easily accessible music you'll like the first time, get Doolittle instead. Songs i like:

Ana
Truly a masterpiece, whenever I put this on it takes me away and it's like i'm hearing it for the first time, what sounds like waves gently breaking, and the smoothest, most ethereal guitar ever recorded. Eleven high, ride a wave.

The Happening
This song pretty much sums up the bands frontman, Black Francis, a strange little alien-obsessed dude who was later to be known as Frank Black. Brilliant stuff, all about a saucer landing on the Vegas Strip, and the later lead guitar work by Joey Santiago is the best I've ever heard by anyone in any song ever; its not fast, but each note is perfect.

Broken Face
There was this boy who had two children with his sisters,
They were his daughters, they were his favourite lovers.

Havalina

Caribou

Hey

Here Comes Your Man



Neutral Milk Hotel
Now if there was one band I could get you to listen to it would be this one.
And if I had to choose one album to listen to for the rest of time it would without doubt be In the Aeroplane Over the Sea by Neutral Milk Hotel.
I simply can't explain how good this album is so instead I'll quote from some reviews from amazon.com to try and make you go download some of their songs and then buy the album.
Quote:
Just from the opening seconds of Neutral Milk Hotel's second album, you know it's going to be special: the acoustic guitar strum is catchy beyond belief, and Jeff Magnum's intonation lends credibility even to a line like "When you were young, you were the King of Carrot Flowers." Listening to In the Aeroplane is like stepping through Alice's looking glass; you enter a fantastic new universe that, while it doesn't always make sense logically, feels like the home you never had.

Quote:
It is no easy task trying to describe original music to someone who has not heard it. Let alone emphasizing the beautiful music they might be missing out on if they don't already own or don't purchase this album. Yes, it is true taste is a relative thing, it's very personal, so with that said all I can say is: Out of the 500 plus records and CD's I own "The Aeroplane over the sea" is quit simply one of my favorites! If I could give it 6 stars I would! I own this album in two forms, CD and vinyl and I'v listened to it hundreds of times while uncontrollably singing along until utter exhaustion. Jeff Mangum is the mad-genius behind this bizarre acoustic-folk-fuzz rock band. He is a song writer who paints abstract pictures with his words. And the songs are so weird yet catchy you can't help.....but to sing along, even though you don't now what the hell you're singing about. I just recieved my 10th anniversary edition of Magnet Magazine and to no surprize this album was there #1 choice for the best of the best albums to come out in the last TEN YEARS!!! Of course, I can't lie a smile of reasurence spread across my face when I first saw that this album was there #1 choice as well. Magnet writes; " Mangum's guitar accomplishes as much with the chords F,G and C as Mexican cuisine does with beans, rice and Flour."

Quote:
If Originality and Sincerity coupled and bore a son this would be the product. Never in all my searches for new and ecclectic music have I ever encountered anything such as this.

Magnum's voice is perfect only in it's imperfections. Often, in my experiences, the best voices (i.e. Bob Dylan, Fiona Apple, Tori Amos etc.) don't run eight octaves but they have the ability to hit you straight in your stomach with one twist of a word. Jeff Magnum does this and does this well.

Quote:
Neutral Milk Hotel is one of those bands that will steal your heart, or send you howling from the room. There's no middle ground. It's an acid-tinged dream of spirituality, sex, chaos, rebirth and beauty, full of girls with roses in their eyes and ghosts flying over stormy cities.

The music tends to be of two types. On one hand, we have Mangum's laid-back folky ballads; they are sometimes laced with other instruments, but the core is his acoustic guitar and his off-kilter voice. And then there are the swirling panoramas of brass-band, fuzz guitar, accordians, white noise, organ and musical saw, among others. These bizarre melodies are entrancing, almost hypnotic, and the catchier ones sound like the soundtrack of a carnival.

http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/B0000019PA/qid=1093128580/sr=ka-1/ref=pd_ka_1/104-0433865-3932763

Go get it now, I don't think it's actually possible to make better music than this. Standout tracks include:

In The Aeroplane Over The Sea

Oh Comely

Holland, 1945

Two-Headed Boy Part I

Two-Headed Boy Part II
In the context of listening to this song at the end of the wonderful album, I would say this is the best song I have ever heard, also with the greatest ending of any song i've come across.



I might post more of my favourite bands later, but for now, please check out these bands. I'd love to know what you think.[/list]

post.author: Johnny B. Goode
post.body:
I'm with der_ton, I like dire straits. I love sultans of swing, that song seems to come on the juke box every time I go to the pool hall.
Other than that, I like Eric Clapton.
I'm surprised nobody's mentioned Stevie Ray Vaughn.
I gotta say, one of my favorite bands is ZZ Top.

Not terribly big into heavy metal, I like some of AC/DC's older stuff, and some of Metallica's older stuff, and for some odd reason I like Rob Zombie. Not a big techno/trance fan either but I kinda like chemical brothers. I mostly like classic rock, chuck berry, elvis, lots of the one shot wonders from back then. For motown, I gotta recomend The Spinners. For blues, just watch the movie Blues Brothers, then buy the soundtrack, or any cd from any of the artists in either of the movies.

I listen to a lot of old music too, louis prima, artie shaw, benny goodman, bob wills. Also got a pretty good collection of music from small local bands. I maintain that the best music these days comes from the bands no one has ever heard of.

I better shut up now, cause I could go on forever.

Johnny

post.author: Renholder
post.body:
I might be the outcast here. Well maybe not.

My top bands are currently ,

Tool - ( last album was lateralus [2001] , Quite frankly .a modern masterpiece , those who haven't heard tool or disliked their previous efforts should check this album out... outstanding stuff)

Incubus- (yeah people say they've gone mellow. I dont believe that crap. They manage to sound original all the time )

Muse- (i've only recently started getting into this British band... Good stuff
A Perfect Circle - ( New album coming out on the 16th..mark your calender.... Thirteenth step...I saw their concert a couple of weeks ago... amazing band.)

That's about it all I'm listening to at this moment...

post.author: Xoalin

Wow, you guys surprise me with your tastes.

Where is the Front 242, Snog, Funker Vogt, Wumpscut, Velvet Acid Christ, Delerium, Absurd Minds, Assemblage 23, Chiasm, etc, etc?!

And come on, has to be at least one closeted musically inclined goth/industrial fan out there... ;) Someone must listen to a little Blutengel...

And no Jazz? What about Duke Elington, Ella Fiztgerald?!

And for those who put down NiN, IF it is the old NiN you like (only good nin in my opinion...) try Skinny Puppy. You should feel an eerie similarity ;)

post.author: jizaboz

ha "Suffocation". Band with 2 black dudes in it... saw them on cable metal music station. Yet ANOTHER metal band with a singer who sounds exactly like cookie monster from Sesame Street heh-heh.

post.author: Dinky
post.body:
jizaboz wrote:
Quote:
Oh, and Linkin Park, but they're not really metal in my opinion.[/QUOTE]


... yeah more like EMO heh-heh

ha "Suffocation". Band with 2 black dudes in it... saw them on cable metal music station. Yet ANOTHER metal band with a singer who sounds exactly like cookie monster from Sesame Street heh-heh.


Linkin Park is sort of like Emo and Boy Bands mixed together (their singing creates the boy-band sound to me). But the guy who makes the actual instrumental part of the music is a genius. Most of the Linkin Park music sounds AMAZING to me until the guys start singing.

Then again it's like that for me and a lot of music. I never listen to lyrics, I just jam to the instruments. So if the singer is over-the-top, then I probably won't like the band unfortunately. Err maybe I shouldn't say over-the-top, maybe I should say that they created their music with trying to center the attention around the singer instead of the actual sound.

I prefer to listen to instrumentals sometimes. Like, here's a REALLY good Joe Satriani song, it's called Searching...

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l_Mq2X2RvBo

post.author: vinnie_jones
post.body:
very nice list DoomUk ! =)
Myself i discovered German synthesizered music lately,
WHAT can one say about Kraftwerk hmm??
classics, esp the Computerwelt album, talk about being
ssooooooo ahead of its time :p
Currently im playing ex-Kraftwerk member Karl Bartos and his stuff,
"Communication" and "Esperanto", it shows in his stuff that he
co-wrote a lot of the aforementioned "Computerwelt"
"watch the news on the screen
is it real or a dream
the whole world at my command
tv guide in my hand
every place every time
politics, sex and crime
I press the key and watch TV"
Totales klassiks ^^

post.author: Renholder
post.body:
I might be the outcast here. Well maybe not.

My top bands are currently ,

Tool - ( last album was lateralus [2001] , Quite frankly .a modern masterpiece , those who haven't heard tool or disliked their previous efforts should check this album out... outstanding stuff)

Incubus- (yeah people say they've gone mellow. I dont believe that crap. They manage to sound original all the time )

Muse- (i've only recently started getting into this British band... Good stuff
A Perfect Circle - ( New album coming out on the 16th..mark your calender.... Thirteenth step...I saw their concert a couple of weeks ago... amazing band.)

That's about it all I'm listening to at this moment...

post.author: Irby
post.body: I agree, Ren. I didn't like any of Tool's previous works, but Lateralus is definately a classic. I still prefer much heavier stuff, though!

Incubus- (yeah people say they've gone mellow. I dont believe that crap. They manage to sound original all the time )

Muse- (i've only recently started getting into this British band... Good stuff
A Perfect Circle - ( New album coming out on the 16th..mark your calender.... Thirteenth step...I saw their concert a couple of weeks ago... amazing band.)

That's about it all I'm listening to at this moment...

post.author: Irby
post.body: I agree, Ren. I didn't like any of Tool's previous works, but Lateralus is definately a classic. I still prefer much heavier stuff, though!

post.author: Renholder
post.body:
I might be the outcast here. Well maybe not.

My top bands are currently ,

Tool - ( last album was lateralus [2001] , Quite frankly .a modern masterpiece , those who haven't heard tool or disliked their previous efforts should check this album out... outstanding stuff)

Incubus- (yeah people say they've gone mellow. I dont believe that crap. They manage to sound original all the time )

Muse- (i've only recently started getting into this British band... Good stuff
A Perfect Circle - ( New album coming out on the 16th..mark your calender.... Thirteenth step...I saw their concert a couple of weeks ago... amazing band.)

That's about it all I'm listening to at this moment...

post.author: Irby
post.body: I agree, Ren. I didn't like any of Tool's previous works, but Lateralus is definately a classic. I still prefer much heavier stuff, though!

post.author: Renholder
post.body:
I might be the outcast here. Well maybe not.

My top bands are currently ,

Tool - ( last album was lateralus [2001] , Quite frankly .a modern masterpiece , those who haven't heard tool or disliked their previous efforts should check this album out... outstanding stuff)

Incubus- (yeah people say they've gone mellow. I dont believe that crap. They manage to sound original all the time )

Muse- (i've only recently started getting into this British band... Good stuff
A Perfect Circle - ( New album coming out on the 16th..mark your calender.... Thirteenth step...I saw their concert a couple of weeks ago... amazing band.)

That's about it all I'm listening to at this moment...

post.author: Irby
post.body: I agree, Ren. I didn't like any of Tool's previous works, but Lateralus is definately a classic. I still prefer much heavier stuff, though!

post.author: jizaboz

Quote:

... yeah more like EMO heh-heh

ha "Suffocation". Band with 2 black dudes in it... saw them on cable metal music station. Yet ANOTHER metal band with a singer who sounds exactly like cookie monster from Sesame Street heh-heh.

post.author: Dinky
post.body:
jizaboz wrote:
Quote:
Oh, and Linkin Park, but they're not really metal in my opinion.[/QUOTE]


... yeah more like EMO heh-heh

ha "Suffocation". Band with 2 black dudes in it... saw them on cable metal music station. Yet ANOTHER metal band with a singer who sounds exactly like cookie monster from Sesame Street heh-heh.


Linkin Park is sort of like Emo and Boy Bands mixed together (their singing creates the boy-band sound to me). But the guy who makes the actual instrumental part of the music is a genius. Most of the Linkin Park music sounds AMAZING to me until the guys start singing.

Then again it's like that for me and a lot of music. I never listen to lyrics, I just jam to the instruments. So if the singer is over-the-top, then I probably won't like the band unfortunately. Err maybe I shouldn't say over-the-top, maybe I should say that they created their music with trying to center the attention around the singer instead of the actual sound.

I prefer to listen to instrumentals sometimes. Like, here's a REALLY good Joe Satriani song, it's called Searching...

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l_Mq2X2RvBo

post.author: Dinky
post.body:
jizaboz wrote:
Quote:
Oh, and Linkin Park, but they're not really metal in my opinion.[/QUOTE]


... yeah more like EMO heh-heh

ha "Suffocation". Band with 2 black dudes in it... saw them on cable metal music station. Yet ANOTHER metal band with a singer who sounds exactly like cookie monster from Sesame Street heh-heh.


Linkin Park is sort of like Emo and Boy Bands mixed together (their singing creates the boy-band sound to me). But the guy who makes the actual instrumental part of the music is a genius. Most of the Linkin Park music sounds AMAZING to me until the guys start singing.

Then again it's like that for me and a lot of music. I never listen to lyrics, I just jam to the instruments. So if the singer is over-the-top, then I probably won't like the band unfortunately. Err maybe I shouldn't say over-the-top, maybe I should say that they created their music with trying to center the attention around the singer instead of the actual sound.

I prefer to listen to instrumentals sometimes. Like, here's a REALLY good Joe Satriani song, it's called Searching...

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l_Mq2X2RvBo

post.author: jizaboz
post.body:
Quote:
Oh, and Linkin Park, but they're not really metal in my opinion.[/QUOTE]


... yeah more like EMO heh-heh

ha "Suffocation". Band with 2 black dudes in it... saw them on cable metal music station. Yet ANOTHER metal band with a singer who sounds exactly like cookie monster from Sesame Street heh-heh.

post.author: Dinky
post.body:
jizaboz wrote:
Quote:
Oh, and Linkin Park, but they're not really metal in my opinion.[/QUOTE]


... yeah more like EMO heh-heh

ha "Suffocation". Band with 2 black dudes in it... saw them on cable metal music station. Yet ANOTHER metal band with a singer who sounds exactly like cookie monster from Sesame Street heh-heh.


Linkin Park is sort of like Emo and Boy Bands mixed together (their singing creates the boy-band sound to me). But the guy who makes the actual instrumental part of the music is a genius. Most of the Linkin Park music sounds AMAZING to me until the guys start singing.

Then again it's like that for me and a lot of music. I never listen to lyrics, I just jam to the instruments. So if the singer is over-the-top, then I probably won't like the band unfortunately. Err maybe I shouldn't say over-the-top, maybe I should say that they created their music with trying to center the attention around the singer instead of the actual sound.

I prefer to listen to instrumentals sometimes. Like, here's a REALLY good Joe Satriani song, it's called Searching...

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l_Mq2X2RvBo

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4Lb9h0J_ajA

Then again it's like that for me and a lot of music. I never listen to lyrics, I just jam to the instruments. So if the singer is over-the-top, then I probably won't like the band unfortunately. Err maybe I shouldn't say over-the-top, maybe I should say that they created their music with trying to center the attention around the singer instead of the actual sound.

I prefer to listen to instrumentals sometimes. Like, here's a REALLY good Joe Satriani song, it's called Searching...

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l_Mq2X2RvBo

post.author: Jack Rammsdell

one of my favorite instrumentals : For the love of god - Steve Vai
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4Lb9h0J_ajA

post.author: Dinky
post.body:
jizaboz wrote:
Quote:
Oh, and Linkin Park, but they're not really metal in my opinion.[/QUOTE]


... yeah more like EMO heh-heh

ha "Suffocation". Band with 2 black dudes in it... saw them on cable metal music station. Yet ANOTHER metal band with a singer who sounds exactly like cookie monster from Sesame Street heh-heh.


Linkin Park is sort of like Emo and Boy Bands mixed together (their singing creates the boy-band sound to me). But the guy who makes the actual instrumental part of the music is a genius. Most of the Linkin Park music sounds AMAZING to me until the guys start singing.

Then again it's like that for me and a lot of music. I never listen to lyrics, I just jam to the instruments. So if the singer is over-the-top, then I probably won't like the band unfortunately. Err maybe I shouldn't say over-the-top, maybe I should say that they created their music with trying to center the attention around the singer instead of the actual sound.

I prefer to listen to instrumentals sometimes. Like, here's a REALLY good Joe Satriani song, it's called Searching...

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l_Mq2X2RvBo

post.author: vinnie_jones
post.body:
very nice list DoomUk ! =)
Myself i discovered German synthesizered music lately,
WHAT can one say about Kraftwerk hmm??
classics, esp the Computerwelt album, talk about being
ssooooooo ahead of its time :p
Currently im playing ex-Kraftwerk member Karl Bartos and his stuff,
"Communication" and "Esperanto", it shows in his stuff that he
co-wrote a lot of the aforementioned "Computerwelt"
"watch the news on the screen
is it real or a dream
the whole world at my command
tv guide in my hand
every place every time
politics, sex and crime
I press the key and watch TV"
Totales klassiks ^^

post.author: vinnie_jones
post.body:
very nice list DoomUk ! =)
Myself i discovered German synthesizered music lately,
WHAT can one say about Kraftwerk hmm??
classics, esp the Computerwelt album, talk about being
ssooooooo ahead of its time :p
Currently im playing ex-Kraftwerk member Karl Bartos and his stuff,
"Communication" and "Esperanto", it shows in his stuff that he
co-wrote a lot of the aforementioned "Computerwelt"
"watch the news on the screen
is it real or a dream
the whole world at my command
tv guide in my hand
every place every time
politics, sex and crime
I press the key and watch TV"
Totales klassiks ^^

WHAT can one say about Kraftwerk hmm??
classics, esp the Computerwelt album, talk about being

Currently im playing ex-Kraftwerk member Karl Bartos and his stuff,
"Communication" and "Esperanto", it shows in his stuff that he
co-wrote a lot of the aforementioned "Computerwelt"
"watch the news on the screen
is it real or a dream
the whole world at my command
tv guide in my hand
every place every time
politics, sex and crime
I press the key and watch TV"
Totales klassiks ^^

post.date: Posted: Sat Feb 12, 2005 7:09 am Post subject:
post.author: Johnny B. Goode
post.body:
I'm with der_ton, I like dire straits. I love sultans of swing, that song seems to come on the juke box every time I go to the pool hall.
Other than that, I like Eric Clapton.
I'm surprised nobody's mentioned Stevie Ray Vaughn.
I gotta say, one of my favorite bands is ZZ Top.

Not terribly big into heavy metal, I like some of AC/DC's older stuff, and some of Metallica's older stuff, and for some odd reason I like Rob Zombie. Not a big techno/trance fan either but I kinda like chemical brothers. I mostly like classic rock, chuck berry, elvis, lots of the one shot wonders from back then. For motown, I gotta recomend The Spinners. For blues, just watch the movie Blues Brothers, then buy the soundtrack, or any cd from any of the artists in either of the movies.

I listen to a lot of old music too, louis prima, artie shaw, benny goodman, bob wills. Also got a pretty good collection of music from small local bands. I maintain that the best music these days comes from the bands no one has ever heard of.

I better shut up now, cause I could go on forever.

Johnny
